comments.commentBody: Rattner is as reliably left as any NYT columnist, but let him stray slightly, let him disturb the sanctity of the echo chamber with objective analysis, and here comes the thought police!

Steve Rattner is promoting fossil fuel commerce.

My thoughts (for many years now) have been filled with information about the destructive effects of fossil fuel production and fossil fuel use. My thoughts have also been filled with information about that industry's enormous business success, the sturdy political support it enjoys in all the countries in which it operates and the relatively few people who receive it's outsize profits. After many years of attention to this torrent of information, my thoughts are not very fond of this bloated, privileged and destructive industry.

My thoughts are shouted down in the American marketplace, as the fossil fuel industry flexes it's political muscles and - now augmented by a new strength in national media - continues to resist development of a renewable energy market. The fossil fuel industry, and Steven Rattner's shill piece are not really interested in my thoughts, my quality of life, my children's world or even my tiny wallet. They're interested in preserving their lucrative status quo. Period. And they're giving just enough money to their employees, sub-contractors, shareholders and media providers to keep a phalanx of foot soldiers on the front line, perpetuating this lucrative status quo.

So Frederick Singer:
Who are the thought police?

I don't know how much longer I can take the oil industry cheerleaders in one of the few remaining newspapers that deserves a teensy bit of respect.

Yeah, Steven, let's just frack away, and keep blowing up the Powder River Basin and it's tributaries for a little coal while we're at it.

I almost was going to tell Steven to go see what fracking and mining look like, but forgot that he never gets out of the house. Unless maybe he gets on a jet for a barbecue in Dallas, with some of the creepiest fake cowboy's you'll ever meet in your life.
It did not accept the Hamas cease fire, which is who they are fighting with.

What I find most insidious about the lack of opportunity in my nation and society is that not only has it logarithmically increased in my lifetime, but that it is pervasive.

Those largely responsible for our social deterioration not only aren't troubled by it, they aggressively lobby and work to institutionalize it and make it fundamental law of the land.

The Koch brothers recent gathering at Dana Point is just an example. http://www.thenation.com/article/180267/exclusive-behind-koch-brothers-s...

http://inewsource.org/2014/06/16/secret-summit-24-hours-with-the-koch-br...

As troubling is the willingness of Conservatives to actively participate. Although few of them would have gained the wealth they have outside the more inclusive United States prior to deregulation, higher taxation, more well funded infrastructure projects, expansive public schools, et al, Conservatives have, since the rise of John Birchers to a seat of respect at the Conservative table, aimed at posting their exclusionary philosophy in government, society, and the work place.

In Jim Crow days the standard signs were "No Negroes Allowed," "Whites Only," etc. Blacks, minorities and women were welcome only in those narrow places defined for them by a racist society.

Now our society deferentially allows the modern equivalent of racism, an attitude that discriminates against those outside the club of haves that control world wealth, and, as importantly, its governments.
.

The OECD's latest report on "Social Justice" reveals a United States that lags most other develped countries in all the major categories from economic mobility to healthcare. This reflects the strength or weakness of the social contract each nation has developed for its citizens. The redistribution of wealth is just one expression of a nation taking care of its own. On this score, we fail miserably.

A few more such victories and Hamas will become the laughing stock of the world, if they are not that already.

If any government can botch something, it is indeed the Arizona State government.  It is time to end this fiasco, if for no other reason than that it is so much cheaper to keep these monsters locked up than to execute them.

While I agree this execution was botched, you cannot know if he suffered.  He may have been unconscious but still breathing during the 2 hours.  What I don't understand is since there are numerous drugs which if given in sufficient quantity will kill, why have three executions used the same failed drug protocol?  It is unclear why no drug manufacturers will supply other drugs than the ones that have recently been shown to prolong the dying process, but that is their right.  It turns out that killing someone neatly and humanely is difficult.

Another botched execution this time performed in the name of the people of the Great State of Arizona. And the US Supreme Court has much to answer for. It allowed this to go forward, quashing a lower court's decision that demanded that Arizona disclosure the drugs to be used and personnel and their qualifications before the execution could be performed. The Supreme Court said that all that was unnecessary. And now, this happens.

To US Supreme Court ... you're as responsible as the people who carried out this experiment in tortured death, the very thing that the 8th Amendment was put in place to end. The 8th Amendment was suppose to mean that drawing and quartering ... or anything like it was not to be allowed in the US, but apparently in this day and age, the chemically induced version of it is ... by order of the US Supreme Court.

I couldn't agree more. However, the United States is insulated/isolated like an island from the rest of the civilized world. If this country identified itself with the civilized world of advanced nations, we would no longer allow the state to execute people, we'd have universal healthcare, etc etc. More and more we seem like a retrograde backwater.

The feelings of the victims' family, which are absolutely legitimate, are often based on a desire for raw revenge (do to him the same he did to the victims). The justice system works according to other principles (to deter future crimes, respect for due process, etc.) so it is not surprising that the victims' families feel at odds with the concerns exhibited by members of the legal profession

Assuming argumento that the sentence was fair, the execution was not.  A two hour execution is cruel, and we are all compromised when the State becomes as cruel as the murderer.  We will be further debased if we, as a society, don't care.

There are, I believe, over 13,000 murders a year in the US. Yet we don't hear of anywhere near that number of executions, even taking into consideration murders committed in states which do not carry or mandate the death penalty for such crimes.

This ought to tell you that courts differentiate between murders and, whilst one might only know by thorough examination of each and every case, I am sure that more than a few cases would be subject to the vagaries of justice brought about by, inter alia, race, gender, sexual orientation, class and religious prejudice - not exactly a recipe for social harmony, justice and a less violent society.

Death penalty is and always will be controversial.  The process is sketchy but eye for an eye needs to applied when such crime is committed.  Joe Wood killed two innocent people, therefore he was sentenced to death.  Its important not to forget what this guy did before seeing what was done.  It was a fair sentence.

I cannot pretend to feel grief that certain murderers will precede me in death (we all get there soon enough) so I will not feign outrage. But the larger issue is: what sort of society do we want to become? By enforcing the death penalty we legitimize murder through judicial bureaucracy and fail to set a higher level of morality than that of the convicted felon.

Our prisons are notoriously corrupt and barbaric. Recent NY Times articles have detailed this abhorrent situation. We were told during the Iraqi War that the incidents of torture and abuse at Abu Ghraib were isolated and not representative of American values. To the contrary, they were all too typical of American prisons, and the complacency with which that is accepted says something unseemly about American values.

Without emotional enthusiasm, but with a longer view of our development as a less violent society, I think we should look toward phasing out capital punishment.

This story and its timing relative to everything thing else that's going on is absolutely surreal. Death comes effortlessly there, death comes for no apparent reason other than because someone had too sophisticated a missile for them known how to use but decided to shoot it anyway and brought down a jet-load of innocent civilians over there.

But here we pretend to exalt the value of life to such a high degree that we will spare no expense to sustain those near death and soon to die anyway, even if that comes at the expense of almost everything else that those with their whole lives ahead of them could benefit from.

But even after convincing ourselves how virtuous we are with this misplaced sacrifice to preserve the sanctity of we deem worthy, we somehow can go on to presume to have the right to take it from those we deem unworthy of having it for it suits or need and satiates our vengeance.

So it is as a result of this glaring contradiction of moral values, is it any wonder that what comes easily everywhere else becomes such a quagmire when trying to pull off. But that disconnect need not matter, because with the legal system we've devised, right and wrong are simply irrelevant trivialities that any good constructed law can't easily navigate around.

That was not a killing in Arizona, simply a long protracted, tortuous expiration of life. Our moral high ground remains intact no matter if Mr. Wood finally did die - gratefully something put him out of his misery.

I have observed this happen to the sister of a murder victim. The sister functioned normally until the killer was investigated for another murder in a death penalty state.  Then the availability of capital punishment drove her crazy with the need for revenge.  The DP creates its own demand.

As it should, unless the death penalty is simply about revenge.

If the death penalty is about revenge, then the victim's family should be allowed to act as executioner and the execution should be televised so that the populace can witness the retribution.

Too morally repugnant? Too corrupting of social morals? If that is the case then the State should not be executing people, in secret, in our name.

Speculator, that was exactly my experience.  Growing up I thought the death penalty just and a deterrent to crime.  As children, we tend to think in black and white.  The accused is the bad guy and the cops and the rest of us are the "good guys".  As I grew older and had many more experiences, I saw that the roles are can be reversed, or a mixture of both.  People are fallible. Witnesses lie, cops lie and so on. There is also the problem of politics and purely crooked dealings.  Sometimes deliberate mishandling occurs so the prosecutor can have another feather in her cap and the victim's family can exact their vile revenge.  The brother-in-law of the victim (Brown) was about as vile as the murderer.  Had the state not murdered the inmate, no doubt he would have is given the opportunity.  The death penalty is too fraught with politics, deceit, self-serving motives and pure black revenge.  This is not how a civilized society acts.
So what was not discerned over Mr. Wood's 25 year wait? The chemical makeup of his execution drug protocol? I think he had his bite at the apple.

As a young man, only just beginning to comprehend such things, I accepted that the death penalty was a just and appropriate punishment for specific heinous crimes. As I've grown older, perhaps I've gained not wisdom, yet I have witnessed the fallibility of my fellow citizens great and small. Who among us is perfect in their wisdom and judgment? Nobody I have ever heard of. So, who are we, any of us, to judge in favor of the death of another? Let he who is without sin cast the first stone.

Since Heroine is a schedule 1 drug, it is probably against Federal law to use it for such a purpose. The US Controlled Substances Act would need to be amended to allow it, and that would take a lot of political doing.

"The point of society killing the most egregious offenders is to create a sense that the state will settle the score - so people don't do it themselves."

As long as you misunderstand the definition of justice, you'll keep arguing this way. But justice and vengeance are not the same thing. The point is not for the state to settle the score. It is to render justice under the law.

If we wanted a society built on vengeance, we wouldn't have an 8th Amendment at all.
